questions.text: A concerned wife brought her 43-year-old husband to the clinic after an episode of light-headedness and palpitations. An ECG was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block.

In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: Bagassosis can be caused due to exposure to all the following except
questions.solution:
Bagassosis is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused in response to exposure of the following antigens present in sugarcane molasses:
• Thermoactinomyces saccheri – main antigen
• Thermoactinomyces vulgaris
• Micropolyspora faeni

While Aspergillus is not associated with Bagassosis, aspergillus species are associated with Tobacco grower's lung.

Farmer's lung is caused by Thermoactinomyces sp.(Micropolyspora faeni also known as Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula) antigen exposure.
Chemical worker's lung is caused by isocyanate exposure

 

Related Pearl: Some common pneumoconiosis

Disease

Exposure

Progressive massive fibrosis

Caplan syndrome

Coal mining (particularly hard coal)

Silica

Caplan syndrome

Metal casting work, sandblasting, hard rock mining, stone cutting, others

Mining, milling, manufacturing, and installation and removal of insulation

questions.text: Barium swallow of a patient presenting with dysphagia is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a patient presenting with dysphagia and a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a hypermotility disorder caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen primarily affecting the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body, with normal deglutitive lower esophageal relaxation (LES) relaxation. These contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude, but normal peristalsis is preserved between the episodes. This condition is seen most often in females.

Patients typically present with dysphagia for both solids and liquids, retrosternal non-cardiac chest pain, and symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation and the sensation of food being stuck in the throat.

Although DES may present as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus on barium swallow, this finding is uncommon. Manometry remains the gold-standard for diagnosis.
 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A critically ill patient who is a registered organ donor collapses even after resuscitative measures. All of the following tests can be used to check the cessation of circulation, except:
questions.solution:
Winslow’s test is used to check the cessation of respiration. In this test a bowl of water is kept on the chest and movement on the surface of the water is noted.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

  • No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes
  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test) - Fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test) - Failure to show redness in the webspace between the fingers on transillumination from behind
  • Icard’s test - Fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration
  • Fingernail test - No blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release

Tests for confirming cessation of breathing:

  • No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes
  • Feather test – No movement of a feather held in front of the nose
  • Mirror test – Mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture of breath
  • Winslow’s test – No movement of the surface of the water in a bowl kept on the chest

questions.text: Depth of inspiration is increased by_____

choices.text: Ventral group of neurons in medulla

questions.solution:
Depth of inspiration is increased by the apneustic center.

The apneustic centre sends signals to prevent switching off of inspiration maintained by the dorsal respiratory group of neurons, thereby increasing depth of inspiration. 

In contrast to this, the pneumotaxic center primarily limits inspiration by controlling the "switch off" point of the inspiratory ramp signal. 

A note on inspiratory ramp signal:

The neural signals transmitted to the inspiratory muscle, mainly the diaphragm, is not the instantaneous burst of action potentials. Instead, it begins weakly and increases steadily in a ramped manner. The advantage of the ramp is that it causes a steady increase in the volume of the lungs during inspiration, rather than inspiratory gasps.

Control of the limiting point at which the ramp suddenly ceases is the mechanism by which the respiratory centers control depth and rate of respiration. 

Option A: Pneumotaxic center of the pons regulates the rate and depth of breathing.
Option B: Ventral group of neurons regulate expiration.
Option C: Dorsal group of neurons regulate inspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cytochrome enzyme inhibitor?
questions.solution:
• Chlorpromazine is a moderate inhibitor of the enzyme CYP2D6.
  • Options A, C and D: Most of the antipsychotics do not inhibit cytochrome enzymes, although most of them are substrates.

Antipsychotics having a significant enzyme (CYP2D6) inhibition property

  • Chlorpromazine
  • Perphenazine
  • Thioridazine

questions.text: You are a field doctor at the site of an earthquake. You assist in rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the likelihood of their survival and need for intervention. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
The process of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention is called triage. It is carried out at the site of disaster.

Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A girl was brought to the clinic by her parents for treatment of alopecia. They gave a history of erythematous vesicular rashes that evolved into verrucous growths a few months after birth. The lesions gradually resolved and left linear pigmentation as shown below. On examination, dental dystrophy was also noted. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of incontinentia pigmenti. It is a rare X-linked dominant disorder with multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males and presents in females with skin lesions, teeth abnormalities, alopecia, nail dystrophy, and ocular and neurological findings.

The skin lesions evolve through the following characteristic stages:

  1. Vesicular
  2. Verrucous stage
  3. Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls
  4. Linear hypopigmentation

questions.text: Bracket calcification on skull X-Ray is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Lipoma of the corpus callosum shows bracket calcification on skull X-ray.

Intracranial lipomas are most commonly located in the midline and are commonly associated with congenital malformations such as agenesis/dysgenesis of the corpus callosum. Pericallosal lipomas are classified into anteriorly located bulky tubulo-nodular type and posteriorly located ribbon-like curvilinear type. Imaging is the mainstay in the diagnosis of intracranial lipoma. 

The image below shows bracket calcification:

Other options:

Option A: Tuberous sclerosis shows calcification of subependymal hamartomas in the wall of the ventricles.

Option B: Sturge Weber syndrome shows tram track calcification.

Option D: Meningioma on X-ray shows calcification hyperostosis and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen in the falx.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete with left apical primary spontaneous pneumothorax was posted for thoracoscopic bullectomy under anesthesia with spontaneous ventilation. Which of the following breathing circuits would be the most effective for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Mapleson's A or Magill circuit is the circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation.

Modified co-axial variety of Type A - Lack's circuit.

SMAL - For Spontaneous, Magill's circuit, Mapleson's Type A, Lack's co-axial circuit

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A patient on regular follow-up for a dermatological condition presents with the following finding. Which of the following conditions is this most likely to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Woronoff's ring is a skin condition characterized by a blanched halo of approximately uniform width surrounding psoriatic lesions after phototherapy or topical treatments.

A major cause of the Woronoff ring is suspected to be due to alterations in prostaglandin metabolism.

questions.text: Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called_____
questions.solution:
• Object permanence is a major developmental milestone, attained at the age of 8-9 months. It is the understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen.
  • Object permanence is firmly established by 18 months of age; toddlers anticipate where an object will end up, even though the object was not visible while it was being moved.

 Other options

  • Separation anxiety – it begins at about 10 mo of age and tapers off by 18 mo.
  • Transitional object – it may be a blanket or a stuffed toy which functions as a symbol of the absent parent.
  • Egocentric symbolic play seen at 12 months - Make-believe (symbolic) play centers on the child’s own body (pretending to drink from an empty cup) ; Symbolic transformations in play are no longer tied to the toddler’s own body by 18 months, so that a doll can be “fed” from an empty plate.

questions.text: A 25-year-old model who is on top of her game comes to get liposuction done. She says she is obese and would like to get rid of the "flabby tissue". On inquiry, it is revealed that she eats high-calorie food multiple times a month and regrets it afterward. She also sometimes skips meals. On examination, BMI is 23, and the finding shown below is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge-eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting.

Bulimia can be differentiated from anorexia nervosa by the following features:

  • The body weight is within the normal range.
  • Bulimia is seen in older age groups (late adolescents or adults).
  • Any peculiar eating habit (like dividing food into small portions) is not seen.
  • Amenorrhoea is not common.
  • Psychiatric symptoms such as depression are more common.

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders- fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders- carbamazepine

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

 

Anorexia nervosa

Bulimia nervosa

Binge-eating disorder

Avoidance of food

(calorie deficit)

+

-

-

Binge eating

+/-

+

+

Compensation

(purge/vomit)

 +/-

+

-

BMI

LOW*

NORMAL (18.5–22.9)

HIGH

 *In atypical anorexia nervosa, all the features of anorexia nervosa will be present, but the patient will have normal BMI.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the acute inflammatory process?

choices.text: It is a mechanism of innate immunity
Monocytes and macrophages are mainly involved
Tissue injury is usually mild and self-limited
Local and systemic signs are prominent

questions.solution:
The prominent cells in acute inflammation are neutrophils.

The initial, rapid response to infections agents and tissue damage is called acute inflammation. It is a mechanism of innate immunity that occurs in response to mild and self-limited tissue injury. It is associated with prominent local and systemic signs.

The major components of acute inflammation are:

  • Vasodilation and increased permeability of small blood vessels 
  • Changes in the leukocytes -
    • Migration from the microcirculation
    • Accumulation at the site of inflammation
    • Activation to eliminate the offending agent

Chronic inflammation is a mechanism of adaptive immunity and is of longer duration. It is associated with

  • Presence of lymphocytes and macrophages
  • Proliferation of blood vessels
  • Deposition of connective tissue

Related Pearl: Comparison of Acute and Chronic Inflammation

Feature

Acute

Chronic

Onset

Rapid: minutes or hours

Slow: days

Cellular infiltrate

Mainly neutrophils

Monocytes/macrophages and lymphocytes

Tissue injury, fibrosis

Usually mild and self-limited

Often severe and progressive

Local and systemic signs

Promient

Less

questions.text: A young child was brought to the ER with a history of loose stools. On examination, she is tachycardic, appears lethargic and skin goes back slowly after the skin pinch test. She was admitted and started on IV fluids and input-output charting was done. The given image shows stool output from the patient. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for the same?

choices.text: Toxin causes Increased guanyl cyclase activity
The toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclase

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dehydration, profuse diarrhea, and rice water stools is suggestive of cholera. Cholera toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclase. 

 Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
  • A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes and the consequent watery diarrhea, that is isotonic with plasma but contains much more of potassium and bicarbonate.
  • The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
  • All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Which of the following are false regarding first-degree burns?

choices.text: Protective functions of the skin are intact
No residual scar after injury heals

questions.solution:
First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, are painful, but do not blister, protective functions of the skin are intact and heals without a scar.

Second-degree burns have dermal involvement and are extremely painful and blister.

Third-degree burns are leathery, painless, and non-blanching.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: Endolymphatic duct connects

choices.text: Scala vestibuli with aqueduct of cochlea

questions.solution:
The endolymphatic duct is formed by the union of two ducts, one each from the saccule and the utricle.

It passes through the vestibular aqueduct. Its terminal part is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone.

The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are filled with perilymph and communicate with each other at the apex of cochlea through an opening called helicotrema.

Aqueduct of cochlea connects scala tympani with subarachnoid space.

questions.text: An infant with poor feeding is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further evaluation reveals hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. This is seen in organic aciduria. 

Organic acidemias most commonly present in infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, hypotonia, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, seizures. Organic acid accumulation inhibits gluconeogenesis and inhibits the urea cycle leading to hyperammonemia.

Common organic acidurias:

  • Methylmalonic aciduria
  • Propionic aciduria
  • Isovaleric aciduria
  • Maple syrup urine disease
  • Glutaric aciduria type I
  • Multiple carboxylase deficiency

questions.text: The most common extracranial solid tumor in pediatric age group is_____
questions.solution:
• Neuroblastoma – is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy and also, the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.
  • It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system.
  • The median age for diagnosis is 22 months and 90% of cases are diagnosed by 5 years of age.
  • Other options:
    • Optic nerve glioma, more properly referred to as juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma, is the most frequent tumor of the optic nerve in childhood.
    • Chloromas, which are collections of myeloid leukemia cells, seen in patients with AML, can occur throughout the neuroaxis.
    • Retinoblastoma is the most common primary malignant intraocular tumor of childhood.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. What is the following finding seen in the patient's post-mortem brain samples known as?
questions.solution:
Fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. The given image thus represents Negri bodies seen in post-mortem brain samples of patients with rabies. 

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

The image below shows Negri bodies:

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, fatigue, hypotension, tachycardia and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria, or malignant tertian malaria, is the most serious malaria. Plasmodium falciparum infects both young and mature erythrocytes, resulting in a large population of erythrocytes affected. Affected erythrocytes display cytoadherence, form rosettes and cause capillary plugging in vital organs like the brain, kidney, lungs etc. Diagnosis is by demonstration of P. falciparum in peripheral blood smear. The peripheral smear findings of falciparum malaria include:

  • Multiple ring forms: Multiple delicate rings are visible within the erythrocytes
  • Double chromatin: Binucleate ring forms resembling stereo headphones
  • Accole form or form applique: Ring forms are attached to the margins of red cells
  • Maurer's dots or clefts: Coarse brick red dots within erythrocytes
  • Banana shaped gametocytes within erythrocytes
  • Absent schizont

The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
Hypnozoites Present Present Absent Absent
Relapse Yes Yes No No
Average IP(days) 14 14 12 (shortest) 30 (longest)
Duration of erythrocyte cycle(hours) 48 (Benign tertian) 48 (ovale tertian) 48 (malignant tertian) 72(Quartan malaria)
Others       Nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not a minor criterion for the diagnosis of myeloma?
questions.solution:
Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy is a major criterion in myeloma diagnosis.

Myeloma criteria

Major criteria

Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy

Bone marrow plasmacytosis with > 30% plasma cells

Monoclonal globulin spike on serum electrophoresis (> 3.5g/dL for IgG, > 2 g/dL for IgA) or on urine (> 1g/24 h of Bence-Jones protein)

Minor criteria

Bone marrow plasmacytosis 10 to 30% plasma cells

Monoclonal globulin spike less than the level defined above

Lytic bone lesions

Reduced normal immunoglobulin (<50% of normal); IgM <0.05 g/dL, IgA < 0.1g/dL, IgG < 0.6 g/d

Diagnostic requirements: The diagnosis of multiple myeloma requires a minimum of one major criterion and one minor criterion or three minor criteria which must include bone marrow plasmacytosis of 10-30 percent and the presence of a monoclonal protein. These criteria must be manifest in a symptomatic patient with progressive disease.

 

Updated Definition of Multiple Myeloma

The revised IMWG criteria will allow, in addition to the classic CRAB features, the following three markers as “myeloma defining events” (MDEs).

  • Sixty percent or greater clonal plasma cells on bone marrow examination
  • Serum involved / uninvolved free light chain ratio of 100 or greater, provided the absolute level of the involved free light chain is at least 100 mg/L (a patient’s “involved” free light chain – either kappa or lambda – is the one that is above the normal reference range; the uninvolved light chain is the one that typically is in, or below, the normal range)
  • More than one focal lesion on MRI that is at least 5 mm or greater in size

The presence of at least one of these markers will be considered sufficient for a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms or CRAB features. Each of these markers has been shown in two or more independent studies to be associated with an approximately 80 percent or higher risk of developing myeloma-related organ damage within two years.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters has been recently included in the Revised Model for end-stage liver disease (MELD) score 3.0 ?
questions.solution:
Albumin level has been recently included in revised MELD score 3.0

Albumin is also included in child turcotte pugh (CTP) score .

 

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

 

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

Variable

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Bilirubin level

<2 mg/dL

2–3 mg/dL

>3 mg/dL

Albumin level

>3.5 g/dL

2.8–3.5 g/dL

<2.8 g/dL

Prothrombin time (increased seconds)

International normalized ratio

1–3

<1.7

4–6

1.7–2.3

>6

>2.3

Encephalopathy

None

Controlled

Uncontrolled

Ascites

None

Controlled

Uncontrolled

Child-Turcotte-Pugh class and overall surgical mortality rates:

  • Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality
  • Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality
  • Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

Prognosis of the various CTP classes:

Class 1-year survival rate  % 2-year survival rate %
A 100 85
B 80 60
C 45 35

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer.

Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetative matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and antibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis.

Mycotic keratitis can be caused by

  • Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium
  • Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus
  • Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and Blastomyces

Typically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. The symptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes.

A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs:

  • Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin.
  • Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epithelium
  • Wessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immune complexes
  • Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer
  • Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterile hypopyon)
  • Perforation is rare
  • Corneal vascularization is usually absent.

A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followed by clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings.

The image below depicts a fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion.

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Infectious uveitis can be caused by the exogenous entry of the organisms following penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcer, and post-intaocular operations.

Acute anterior uveitis presents with symptoms of pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blurring of vision and redness of the eye. Signs of anterior uveitis include: 

  • Aqueous flare -  It is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis, it occurs following the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor.
  • Keratic precipitates(KP) - These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. They are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of the cornea arranged in a triangular fashion. These include mutton fat KP's as seen in granulomatous uveitis and granular KP's of non granulomatous uveitis.
  • Iris nodules: typically occur in granulomatous uveitis. Koppe's nodules are at the pupillary border and Busacca's nodules are situated near the collarette.

Option C: Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva of which the bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by marked conjunctival hyperemia, swelling of the conjunctiva(chemosis), edematous eyelids, sticking together of lid margins and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.

The image shows a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis.

Option D: Corneal laceration: Partial corneal laceration or lamellar corneal laceration occurs from a blunt trauma and is treated by patching and antibiotics.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of pathological myopia?
questions.solution:
Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Complications of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Macular degeneration
  • Retinal detachment
  • Complicated cataract
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Strabismus fixus convergence
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia.

questions.text: Poisoning with which of the following compounds causes mydriasis?
questions.solution:
Endrin is an organochlorine compound. Poisoning with this compound causes mydriasis. There is no specific antidote for organochlorine poisoning.

Diazinon, phosdrin, and paraoxon are organophosphates and they cause miosis. Organophosphate poisoning is treated with atropine and oximes.

Classification of insecticides:

  • Organophosphorus compounds
    • Parathion
    • Paraoxon
    • Chlorthion
    • Diazinon
    • Malathion
    • Phosdrin
    • HETP (hexaethyl tetraphosphate)
    • TEPP (tetraethyl pyrophosphate)
  • Organochlorine compounds
    • DDT (dichloro diphenyl trichloroethane)
    • Gammahexa-chlorobenzene
    • Endrin
    • Aldrin
    • Endosulfan
  • Carbamates
    • Aldicarb
    • Carbaryl
    • Carbofuran
  • Pyrethrin and pyrethroids

questions.text: The treatment of choice for congenital cataract is _______.

choices.text: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant

questions.solution:
Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant is the treatment of choice in congenital cataract.

Cataract surgery for congenital cataract includes Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy.

Intracapsular cataract extraction [ICCE] is contraindicated in children.

After removal of the cataractous lens, posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted.

Timing of surgery

The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is 2–4 months of age.

Any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred.

  • Bilateral dense cataract: early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age
  • Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis: urgent surgery within days

Note: Though some references recommend contact lenses over PCIOL in certain contexts, most Indian pediatric ophthalmologists prefer PCIOL in all age groups.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents an enzymatic reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. 

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 (v0 - initial velocity) is plotted versus 1/[S] ([S] - substrate concentration) and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors. The x-intercept represents -1/Km while the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax. 

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at the same -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

Note: An allosteric inhibitor alters the conformation of an enzyme upon binding. Enzymes affected by allosteric inhibitors exhibit a sigmoid, not hyperbolic, relationship between V0 and [S].

questions.text: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces are present.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways:

  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • Oligomenorrhoea
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Habitual abortions
  • Infertility

The causes of Asherman syndrome are:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

questions.text: Blighted ovum is characterized by

choices.text: Absence of fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 10mm
Absence of fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 12 mm
Absence of fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 20mm
Absence of fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 15mm

questions.solution:
Blighted ovum (silent miscarriage):

  • 50% of miscarriages are anembryonic, that is, with no identifiable embryonic elements.
  • It is a sonographic diagnosis.
  • An anembryonic gestation (in blighted ovum) is when mean gestational sac diameter is more than equal to 20mm and no embryo is seen.
  • Uterus is to be evacuated once the diagnosis is made.

questions.text: All of the following are the products obtained in the uronic acid pathway in humans, except:
questions.solution:
Vitamin C is not a product of the uronic acid pathway in humans.

Glucuronic acid, pentose sugars, proteoglycans are all the products obtained in the uronic acid pathway in humans.

In the liver, the uronic acid pathway is the source of glucuronic acid for conjugation of many endogenous and exogenous substances before excretion as glucuronides in urine and bile.

The lack of one enzyme of the uronic acid pathway called L-gulonolactone oxidase in primates and some other animals including human beings explains why ascorbic acid (vitamin C) cannot be endogenously synthesized. Hence, it is a dietary requirement for human beings.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a lower abdominal mass for the past 2 years. She had undergone uterine artery embolisation for fibroids 5 years ago. Ultrasound showed a homogeneous mass near the uterine fundus. On exploratory laparotomy,  the mass was observed to be attached to the greater omentum and it was excised. Histopathology of the mass is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid.  The given histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei that are characteristic of a fibroid.

A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its blood supply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite of uterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection.

Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium. 

Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increase in size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology.

Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritoneal surfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding elastic arteries?

choices.text: They are also known as distributing arteries
The internal elastic lamina is distinct from the tunica media
Smooth muscles are absent in the tunica media
The elastic recoil helps in continuous flow of the blood

questions.solution:
The elastic recoil of the elastic arteries helps in continuous blood flow.

The large elastic arteries distend and recoil during systole and diastole respectively due to abundant elastic tissue. The recoiling acts as an additional force that pushes blood into smaller arteries. So, blood flows continuously through arteries but with some fluctuation in pressure during systole and diastole.

The main differences between the elastic and muscular arteries are shown in the table given below:

Structure Elastic artery Muscular artery
Tunica intima The internal elastic lamina cannot be distinguished from the surrounding tunica media The internal elastic lamina is distinct
Tunica media

Predominantly of elastic fibers.
Few smooth muscle cells.

 Predominantly of smooth muscle cells.
Very few elastic fibers.
Tunica adventitia Relatively thin and consists mainly of elastic fibers Relatively thicker and consists of fibroblastic tissue.

Other options:

Option A: The elastic arteries are also known as conducting vessels, as their main function is to conduct the blood from the heart, whereas the muscular arteries are known as distributing vessels.

Option B: The internal elastic lamina in the elastic arteries is not distinct and cannot be differentiated from the tunica media as the structure of the internal elastic lamina is same as that of the elastic fibers present in tunica media of elastic arteries.

Option C: The tunica media of the elastic arteries is predominantly made up of elastic tissue. Between the elastic membranes, there is some loose connective tissue. Some smooth muscle cells may be present.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Ortner's syndrome is a rare cause of left (unilateral) recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy due to compression by enlarged cardiac structures such as the left atrium or pulmonary artery.

Causes of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy:

  • Thyroid surgery
  • Neck trauma
  • Thyroid malignancy
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy.

Though the risk of bilateral nerve involvement is much less than unilateral, it is possible. Depending on whether the palsy is unilateral or bilateral, findings will differ.

Terminologies in vocal cord palsy:

  • Pure RLN palsy: abductor palsy (the only abductor, posterior cricoarytenoid is affected)
  • Pure SLN palsy: rare (only cricothyroid, one of the adductors and the main tensor is affected)
  • Complete paralysis: both SLN and RLN are involved.

questions.text: What is the arterial supply of the structure labelled in the picture with the blue dotted line?

choices.text: Artery from the left posterior aortic sinus

questions.solution: The image shows a triangle of Koch marked with blue dotted lines. The arterial supply to the triangle of Koch is from the right coronary artery in the majority of the population.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a fever and cough. She has a history of repeated chest infections for several years and coughs up yellow-green purulent sputum with some streaky hemoptysis. What could be the underlying condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.

A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding immune thrombocytopenic purpura is false?

choices.text: Acute ITP occurs following viral infections
Lymphocytosis is rare in chronic ITP
Chronic ITP is commonly seen in males
Spontaneous remission is common in acute ITP

questions.solution:
Chronic ITP is more common in females.

Acute ITP Chronic ITP
Common in children Common in adults (females > males)
No sex predilection More common in females
Associated with antecedent viral infection Not associated with antecedent infection
Spontaneous remission within 6 months in most cases Spontaneous remission is not usually seen

questions.text: The blood picture below shows cells with ‘flower shaped nucleus’ characteristic of_____
questions.solution:
• Anaplastic large T/null-cell lymphoma was previously usually diagnosed as undifferentiated carcinoma or malignant histiocytosis.
  • Peripheral blood smear showing leukemia cells with typical “flower-shaped” nucleus.
  • The diagnosis of anaplastic large T/null-cell lymphoma is made when an expert hematopathologist recognizes the typical morphologic picture and a T-cell or null-cell immunophenotype with CD30 positivity.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus?
questions.solution:
The sciatic nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus. It is the largest branch of the sacral plexus.

Related Pearl: Sacral Plexus

Sacral plexus is formed from the ventral rami of L4–S4 spinal nerves. 

The following table shows the branches of sacral plexus, their root value, muscles innervated, and cutaneous branches. 

Nerve

(From dorsal division of S1, S2 and ventral division of S2, S3)

 

Posterior cutaneous femoral

• Inferior cluneal nerves

• Perineal branches

Muscles of the pelvic floor:

Levator ani

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test and states that her LMP was 8 weeks ago. However, she has a history of irregular cycles. Which of the following would be the most accurate way of dating the pregnancy?

choices.text: Abdominal circumference on transabdominal or transvaginal USG
Crown rump length on transabdominal or transvaginal USG

questions.solution: The most accurate way of dating the pregnancy is using the crown-rump length (CRL) on transabdominal or transvaginal USG. It has a variance of about 3 to 5 days.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought with abdominal swelling. On examination, a mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant.  Laboratory evaluation shows serum alpha-fetoprotein level of 1,50,000 ng/mL. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level are suggestive of hepatoblastoma.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually < 3 years. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the most important clinical marker for hepatoblastoma. It remains the key clinical marker of malignant change, response to the treatment, and relapse.

Histological section of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells is given below.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Microcytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Thalassemia trait

Basophilic stippling, target cells 

Iron-deficiency

Elliptocytes, target cells

Sideroblastic anemia

Pappenheimer bodies, RBC dimorphism, ringed sideroblasts (Perl’s stain) 

Macrocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Myelodysplastic syndrome

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency 

Heinz bodies (revealed by special staining),‘Bite’ cells

questions.text: The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in ____________
questions.solution:
The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in distributive shock.

It is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. The most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis.

The causes of vasodilatation in various types of distributive shock:

Type of distributive shock  Cause of vasodilatation 
Septic shock  Release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system. 
Anaphylactic shock  Histamine release 
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury)  Failure of sympathetic outflow and adequate vascular tone 

The following Table shows cardiovascular and metabolic characteristics of different types of shock.

  Hypovolemia Cardiogenic Obstructive Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low

High (in septic and anaphylactic shock)

Low (in neurogenic shock)
Vascular resistance High High High Low
Venous pressure Low High High Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High
Base deficit High High High High

questions.text: The blood-testis barrier is formed by______

choices.text: Tight junctions between adjacent leydig cells
Tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells.

This Sertoli-Sertoli cell tight junctions divide the seminiferous epithelium into 2 compartments:

  • Basal compartment - contains the spermatogonia and early-stage primary spermatocytes.
  • Adluminal compartment - contains later-stage primary spermatocytes and all subsequent stages of sperm cells.

It imparts a selective permeability, allowing few substances such as testosterone to cross but preventing noxious substances that might damage the developing sperm. It also protects sperms from antibodies by creating a specialized, immunologically safe microenvironment for developing sperm.

 

BELOW DIAGRAM - 

1 basal lamina, 2 spermatogonia, 3 spermatocyte 1st order, 4 spermatocyte 2nd order, 5 spermatid, 6 mature spermatid, 7 Sertoli cell, 8 tight junctions(Blood- Testis Barrier)

questions.text: Which of the following is a urinary antiseptic?
questions.solution:
Methenamine is a urinary antiseptic and is indicated in urinary tract infections. At pH<5.5, methenamine releases formaldehyde that inhibits bacteria. 

Option A: Galantamine is a central anticholinesterase approved for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

Option C: Mecamylamine is a ganglionic blocker that can be used as an antihypertensive agent.

Option D: Pyrimethamine is an antimalarial agent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: While conducting a field study in a village, you found the birth and death rates of the population to be 42 and 31 respectively. What is the current annual growth rate of this population?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the current annual growth rate is 1.1%.

Here, the birth rate is 42 i.e 42 live births per 1000 population, and the death rate is 31 i.e 31 deaths per 1000 population. 

Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate. So, current annual growth rate = 42-31= 11 per 1000 population or 1.1%.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of protein quality?

choices.text: Protein digestibility corrected amino acid score

questions.solution:
Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator for protein quality.

DIAAS reflects the digestibility of individual amino acids in the protein. Total protein digestibility does not always reflect the digestibility of individual dietary indispensable amino acids. Hence, DIAAS has replaced the PDCAAS (protein digestibility corrected amino acid score) as the preferred index for the evaluation of protein quality.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of Parkinson disease on treatment for the past 10 years is complaining of hallucinations. From which of the following drugs, will the patient be benefited?
questions.solution:
Pimavanserin is an atypical antipsychotic approved for use in delusions and hallucinations associated with Parkinson’s disease.

It has a unique mechanism of action of antagonism and inverse agonism at 5-HT2A receptors with no action on dopamine receptors.
